Literature Review: Plant hormones play a crucial role in regulating growth, development, and responses to environmental stimuli in plants. These small signaling molecules, produced at very low concentrations, have the remarkable ability to move within plants and exert their effects at distant sites. The transport and localization of plant hormones are essential for maintaining hormone homeostasis and coordinating various physiological processes. This literature review aims to summarize the current understanding of plant hormone transport mechanisms, focusing on the characterized transporters, their biochemical and physiological roles, and their significance in plant development.Auxin, one of the most extensively studied plant hormones, has been shown to rely on a complex network of transporters for its distribution. The PIN-FORMED (PIN) family of efflux carriers plays a central role in directional auxin transport. Petrášek et al. (2006) demonstrated that PIN proteins are essential for cellular auxin efflux and polar auxin transport. The localization of PIN proteins is highly dynamic and can be rapidly altered in response to environmental cues, allowing for precise control of auxin gradients (Kleine-Vehn et al., 2008).In addition to PINs, the AUXIN1/LIKE-AUX1 (AUX1/LAX) family of influx carriers contributes to auxin uptake into cells. Swarup et al. (2008) showed that AUX1 is crucial for gravitropic responses in Arabidopsis roots by facilitating auxin uptake into specific cell types. The interplay between influx and efflux carriers creates local auxin maxima and gradients, which are essential for various developmental processes, including organ formation and tropic responses.Abscisic acid (ABA) transport has also been the subject of intense research due to its importance in stress responses and seed dormancy. Kang et al. (2010) identified ABCG25 as an ABA exporter, while Kanno et al. (2012) characterized ABCG40 as an ABA importer. These discoveries highlighted the bidirectional nature of ABA transport and its significance in regulating ABA responses in different tissues.Cytokinin transport, although less well-understood compared to auxin, has been shown to involve both active and passive mechanisms. Bürkle et al. (2003) identified the purine permease family (PUP) as potential cytokinin transporters, with PUP1 and PUP2 facilitating cytokinin uptake. More recently, Zürcher et al. (2016) characterized the ABCG14 transporter as essential for root-to-shoot translocation of cytokinins, demonstrating the importance of long-distance hormone transport in coordinating whole-plant responses.Gibberellins (GAs) are another class of plant hormones with significant roles in growth and development. Kanno et al. (2016) identified NPF3, a member of the NRT1/PTR FAMILY (NPF), as a GA transporter involved in GA uptake and long-distance transport. This discovery provided insights into how GA distribution is regulated and highlighted the potential involvement of NPF proteins in the transport of multiple plant hormones.Ethylene, unique among plant hormones due to its gaseous nature, does not require specific transporters for movement within plants. However, the precursor of ethylene, 1-aminocyclopropane-1-carboxylic acid (ACC), is actively transported. Shin et al. (2015) characterized LYSINE HISTIDINE TRANSPORTER1 (LHT1) as an ACC transporter, revealing a mechanism for regulating ethylene biosynthesis and signaling through precursor transport.Jasmonic acid (JA) and its derivatives play crucial roles in plant defense and stress responses. Ishimaru et al. (2011) identified the ATP-binding cassette (ABC) transporter ABCG16 as a potential JA-Ile transporter in rice, suggesting a role in systemic defense signaling. However, the mechanisms of JA transport remain less well-characterized compared to other plant hormones, highlighting an area for future research.The subcellular localization of hormone transporters is another critical aspect of hormone transport and signaling. Many transporters exhibit polar localization within cells, which is essential for creating directional hormone fluxes. For example, the polar localization of PIN proteins is crucial for establishing auxin gradients during various developmental processes (Wiśniewska et al., 2006).The existence of multiple transporters for the same hormone raises questions about their functional redundancy and specificity. Barbez et al. (2012) demonstrated that the PIN-LIKES (PILS) family of putative auxin carriers regulates intracellular auxin homeostasis, suggesting that different transporter families may have distinct roles in regulating hormone levels at various cellular and subcellular locations.In conclusion, the transport and localization of plant hormones are complex processes involving multiple families of transporters with varying substrate specificities and subcellular localizations. These transport mechanisms are crucial for maintaining hormone homeostasis and coordinating plant growth and development. Future research should focus on elucidating the interplay between different transporter families, their regulation in response to environmental stimuli, and their roles in integrating multiple hormone signaling pathways. Understanding these intricate transport networks will provide valuable insights into plant hormone biology and potentially lead to novel strategies for improving crop productivity and stress tolerance.
